msDesc.head: Portable Secular Psalter with Antiphons; Italy, North-East, 15th century, third quarter

msItem.title: Psalter
msItem.note: Fols. i–iii are paper fly-leaves, blank apart from modern and early modern notes (see ‘Provenance’).

Litany, including Vitalis (of Ravenna (?)) and Apollinaris (of Ravenna (?)) among the martyrs; Leonard (of Brescia (?)), Dominic and Francis among the confessors; Antonia (of Aquila, or of Brescia (?)) and Anthia among the virgins. Followed by collects with rubrics ‘oratio’ (fol. 159r–v):
(1) Clamantes ad te deus dignanter exaudi ...
(2) Liberator animarum mundi redemptor ...
(3) Suscipere digneris domine deus hos psalmos ... The last two prayers use feminine grammatical forms, e.g. ‘supplico ego misera’, ‘famula tua’ (fol. 159r), ‘indigna famula tua’ (fol. 159v). Fol. 160 is ruled but blank, apart from modern notes; fols. 161–163 are paper fly-leaves, blank apart from modern notes.

supportDesc.collation: (fols. i–iii) paper fly-leaves; fols. i–ii are a bifolium | (fols. 1–160) I–XVI (10) | (fols. 161–163) paper fly-leaves; fols. 162–163 are a bifolium. Catchwords, some partly cropped off, and leaf signatures often survive

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in pale ink with single vertical bounding lines extending the full height of page; 21 lines per page; written below the top line; written space: c. 90 62

handDesc.handNote: Formal Gothic book hand, black ink, smaller script used for antiphons, etc.

decoDesc.decoNote: fol. 1r Psalm 1 (initial B(eatus)) 9-line initial, decorated with foliage, on gold background, infilled with half-figure of King David playing psaltery.

(full border) Rectangular border, outlined in gold, decorated with filigree scrolls, flowers, foliage and gold discs; medallion with a dove in rays of light in the right margin. In the lower margin two winged putti support a laurel wreath with an overpainted coat of arms.

One 9-line (psalm 109, fol. 107r) and six 8-line initials, decorated with foliage, on gold background, with sprays of filigree scrolls, foliage, flowers and gold discs extending into margins, at liturgical divisions at psalms 26 (fol. 21v), 38 (fol. 34v), 52 (fol. 47r), 68 (fol. 60r), 80 (fol. 76r) and 97 (fol. 91r).
2-line alternating red and blue initials, decorated with contrasting purple or red penwork, at the beginnings of psalms, canticles, prayers, litany and hymns.
1-line alternating plain red and blue initials at the beginnings of verses and periods.

binding.p:
18th century, middle (by 1751), Italian: pasteboards; polished, hard, near-black leather, heavily grained (like shagreen?), plain except for blind triple lines around edges of covers; two fine fore-edge clasps, comprising straps of the same leather with scallop-shaped tips and loops of dark metal which fit onto pins at edges of lower cover; paste-downs of marbled paper; flyleaves of thick white laid paper, with an ex dono inscription dated 1762 (fol. iiir) and the date ‘1751’ at end (fol. 161v, cf. 160v).
160–161 116–117 c. 35–36 (book closed). Identical clasps are at MS. Canon. Liturg. 291, but with different binding style.

history.provenance: Made in the north-east of Italy, perhaps in Ravenna or Brescia: evidence of the litany. Written for a woman: feminine grammatical forms in prayers on fol. 159r–v. Shield of arms, painted over, on fol. 1r.
‘Ex dono f: [or J?] M: A: D: Danielis Adelardi anno 1764’, fol. iii recto, possibly by Canonici.
‘1751’ written in ink on fols. 160v and 161v.
Matteo Luigi Canonici of Venice (1727–c. 1806), but not from the libraries of Soranzo or Trevisan (Mitchell, 1969).
history.acquisition: Bodleian Library: bought in 1817 from Canonici’s nephew Giovanni Perissinotti. Earlier shelfmarks: ‘73’ (fol. i recto); ‘E codd. Bodl. Miscell. Liturg. 158.’ (fol. iii verso).
